awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Calibrating the end-Ediacaran Extinction with U-Pb Geochronology & Chemostratigraphy at a New Precambrian-Cambrian Boundary Site in Namibia & South Africa
awd_abstract_narration:
The first appearance and rapid diversification of complex, multicellular animals at the dawn of the Cambrian (~540 million years ago) is conceivably the single most significant episode in the evolution of life on Earth, as it laid out the initial blueprints for the vast majority of life forms that exist today. Understanding the driving mechanisms of the Cambrian 'explosion' have been challenging because life forms that dominated the preceding period, the Ediacaran, have a sparse fossil record. In addition, the marine sedimentary rocks that preserve the Ediacaran-Cambrian transition are now scattered across the continents, hampering an unequivocal reconstruction of life and the environment at this crucial junction of the geologic history. This study focuses on key outcrops of the Ediacaran-Cambrian marine deposits with spectacular fossils and high potential for precise isotopic dating in a previously unexplored region near the Namibia-South Africa border. The results will provide new insights into the rates of paleoenvironmental and ocean chemical change during this critical time interval. In addition to public presentations and scholarly publications, a comprehensive program of educational, training, and outreach activities are planned.

This project employs an integrated program of field mapping, sedimentology, chemo- and bio-stratigraphy on newly discovered marine carbonate-rich and fossiliferous Ediacaran-Cambrian sections on either side of the Orange River in Namibia and South Africa with abundant intercalated ash beds suitable to U-Pb geochronology. It will provide a high-resolution record that will help to unravel the mode and rates of biotic and coeval environmental changes at the close of the Proterozoic. The results will be a major step forward in testing the hypothesis that there were globally synchronous environmental perturbations that were genetically associated with biotic turnover across the Ediacaran-Cambrian boundary, and will lead to a better understanding of the driving mechanisms of the Cambrian radiation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was an integrated stratigraphic, geochemical and geochronologic study focused on a newly investigated geologic site on the border of Namibia and Republic of South Africa, which preserves a near complete sedimentary record of the Ediacaran – Cambrian transition. This transition marks one the most consequential stages in the evolution of multicellular life on the planet, known as the Cambrian explosion, which took place at the dawn of the Paleozoic Era nearly 540 million years ago (Ma). The timing and pace of this evolutionary event, as well as its global synchroneity, are essential to understanding its paleoenvironmental causes and consequences. Although the tempo of Ediacaran – Cambrian transition has been the subject of intensive research for over three decades, progress has been complicated due to a paucity of complete stratigraphic records with well-preserved fossils and suitable rocks for radioisotopic age determination.

Under this project, the research team carried out two seasons of field work in the Orange River area (Neint Nababeep Plateau) of South Africa and Namibia to collect field observations, as well as fossils, sedimentary rock samples to study ocean chemistry and interbedded volcanic ash for U-Pb geochronology. The major scientific outcomes of this project include: (1) a detailed geologic map and stratigraphic framework for a new, expanded, Ediacaran – Cambrian boundary succession, (2) new carbon isotope chemostratigraphy, (3) new high-precision U-Pb geochronology directly integrated with stratigraphy, and (4), the highest resolution Bayesian age-stratigraphic model to date for any Ediacaran – Cambrian boundary succession globally, which provides precise temporal context for the corresponding oceanic geochemical and paleontological records. Our results reveal an unambiguous time line for the extinction of documented Ediacaran life forms and the emergence of bilaterian fauna with complex burrows akin to those marking the earliest Cambrian. According to our new chronostratigraphic model, this key faunal transition occurs over a ca. 300 meters stratigraphic interval bracketed in age between 539.18+0.17/−0.26 Ma and 538.30+0.14/−0.14 Ma, suggesting that the Cambrian explosion could have started at an even younger age and thus in a more abrupt manner than previously predicted. The results of this project have been published in student-led peer-reviewed journal articles and have been disseminated through multiple presentations at national conferences.

This project has had important implications for an NSF-supported International Continental Scientific Drilling Program (ICDP) project dedicated to recovering continuous records of the Ediacaran – Cambrian transition on three paleocontinents (GRIND-ECT). The drilling project includes sites in Namibia, the selection of which has been guided in part by the results of this project. Our combined results will be consequential to the fields of paleobiology and evolutionary biology and defines a step forward in understanding the complex interrelationships among solid Earth, paleoenvironmental change and biologic evolution in deep time.

Multiple students and research staff received education and training in geologic mapping, sedimentary geology, geochronology and stable isotope geochemistry while contributed to this project. The project constituted for the most part the PhD dissertation research of a Johns Hopkins student, who is now an assistant professor at MIT. Two other Johns Hopkins students received training during visits to the MIT isotope Lab. The project supported the work of two MIT technical staff, one of whom is now a research geologist at USGS and another has completed her PhD at the University of Vermont.
